awd_titl_txt: ATD: Threat Detection Problems in Precision Agriculture and Satellite Imaging
awd_abstract_narration:
This project explores possible techniques for threat detection by leveraging research into related unsolved problems in precision agriculture and satellite imaging. Some of these problems are currently solved in a laboratory setting but do not have satisfying solutions in the practical setting of remote sensing. In addition to security benefits, the research has the potential to save growers money and reduce the environmental impact of agriculture by applying only the inputs that are needed only when and where they are needed. The project's contributions to satellite imaging and measurement would also enhance environmental monitoring. Efficient remote sensing would enable accurate threat detection from minimal amounts of data, while increasing the life span of scanners and reducing associated costs.

This project aims to develop crucial methods for the data cleaning and processing necessary to ensure meaningful results in aerial and satellite imagery. For example, the investigators will explore a careful and novel approach to cloud removal in satellite images. A new approach is necessary since the measurement of vegetation indices, which help identify various threats to crops, becomes unreliable in the presence of shadows introduced by clouds. The investigator and collaborators will also address the technical problem of image stitching, or solving large puzzles, for agricultural fields. The difficulty here is that patches are very similar to each other and sometimes have very little overlap. Other technical problems to be studied are super-resolution and inpainting in non-uniform settings. Once these technical problems are solved, the investigators plan to adapt and further develop techniques for threat detection, in particular, techniques for multivariate change point detection. Robust threat detection in agriculture will also help to optimize crop yield while minimizing resources. Thus, advances in threat detection capabilities in these domains broadly impact society even beyond their intrinsic usefulness.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project addressed problems in threat detection. Since real datasets for some of these problems are often hard to obtain, many of the studies were motivated by specific problems and datasets from precision agriculture, satellite imaging and medical data-driven problems.

Neural networks have become prevalent in threat detection. They often obtain impressive accuracy for some threat detection problems, but on the other hand they are not sufficiently understood and are often used as black boxes. Therefore, part of the project aimed to explain neural networks or modify them to obtain better explainability.     

In particular, the project developed a graph convolutional neural network based on a graph scattering transform. The scattering transform was previously proposed for standard signals and images, but the project generalized it to graphs and consequently addressed new and important application areas, such as social networks. The proposed method obtains features in a constructive and well-understood way, whereas in standard neural networks the learning of the features is considered as a black box. This part of the project culminated in a proof that under certain conditions, any feature generated by such a network is approximately invariant to permutations and stable to graph manipulations.  Furthermore, numerical results demonstrated competitive performance on relevant datasets. The project further used the proposed graph scattering network for graph generation tasks and, in particular, for molecule generation.

To better interpret features obtained by standard neural networks in special applications, the PI collaborated with researchers from the Mayo clinic on explaining neural networks for electrocardiogram (ECG) signal analysis. In this setting, the detection of diseases is a special case of threat detection. ECG analysis has been performed for many years resulting in a very rich and biologically meaningful vocabulary of features. As the mechanism behind the features in the vocabulary is known, translating the neural networks rules to these human features provides a direct link to the biology that drives the neural network decision. The PI and his collaborators showed that neural networks for ECG signals extract features in a similar manner to human experts and that they also generate additional novel features that help achieve superior performance. 

To further advance threat detection, the project developed a neural network for unsupervised anomaly detection by incorporating a novel robust subspace recovery layer. The competitive precision and recall by this network was carefully demonstrated for image datasets. 

The project proposed a novel mathematical framework to address the mathematical problem of automatically solving large jigsaw puzzles. It also numerically demonstrated the competitive performance of the proposed method. The code was discussed and provided to a local precision agriculture company in order to address difficult scenarios of the image stitching (or mosaicking) problem with aerial images.

The project also proposed new and improved variational data assimilation approaches. Data assimilation effectively combines information from both a dynamical model and the measurement data. It is natural to apply it for some threat detection problems with a known dynamical model; for example, it has been used for the prediction of COVID-19 spread. The project proposed new approaches for the formal treatment of bias in both model outputs and observations. Under positive systematic biases in both model and observations, the proposed method consistently demonstrated a significant reduction in the forecast bias and unbiased root‐mean‐squared error. The project further developed additional approaches addressing nontrivial forecasting problems, where the underlying distributions of the background state and observations are non-Gaussian. This approach was successfully applied to dissipative and chaotic evolutionary dynamics and showed promising results even for high-dimensional problems. 

The project addressed additional important problems, for example, it developed fast algorithms for semi-supervised learning problems on graphs with very few labels and demonstrated competitive numerical results for classification and regression problems on graphs.

All of the above mathematical approaches were applied to solve scientific problems and had a clear broader impact beyond the area of mathematics. To make the work accessible to the practitioners, all codes and products were made publicly available. Additional broader impacts included guiding graduate and undergraduate students in research, while working with a diverse group. The most significant and non-standard educational activities of the PI aimed to prepare students for successful careers in industry. For this purpose, the PI organized the industrial problems seminar, where leading researchers from industry discussed their research problems and their transition from an academic environment to leadership in industry, and met with students. The PI also co-organized the IMA data science seminar. Attending these seminars and meeting with the speakers helped students prepare themselves for industry. The talks and their materials are available online to the wider community. During the pandemic some of the talks were virtually attended by more than 100 participants. The PI also helped organize industrial internships for undergraduate and graduate students and created and updated freely-available online resources for internships.
